body:
As the issue template explains, please use the [forum](https://forum.syncthing.net/) for support.
Please use the search on the forum and the closed issue tracker for simillar issues before starting a new thread. 
If this issue is later proven to be a bug, we will reopen this issue or open a new one.
This does actually sound like a real bug though to me. Symlinks between two windows boxes should certainly not cause permission errors. I'd like for someone to see if this is reproducible or not.

Just some more info. I fired up an older Windows VM that was at Syncthing v0.14.6 and have documented with screenshots what happens under Windows between a new version of Syncthing v0.14.24 and the older 0.14.6 version, then upgrading the older machine to the latest version of Syncthing.

The screenshots are here: https://1drv.ms/f/s!AqWtxefKp-f5nla2eMKXHG6PCo9x
There's one screenshot taken from each machine and given a matching number (so 1 - Fractal to Scratch, matches 1 - Scratch to Fractal.)

Images no. 1) Two folders had been previously shared between them and they must have contained a symlink, Fractal (at 0.14.24) warns it won't sync symlinks, and Scratch (at 0.14.6) won't finish syncing.

Images no 2) I share a new folder (TestNoSymlinks) and stop sharing the older folders that must contain symlinks - syncing completes for both machines.

Images no 3) I share a new folder (TestSymlinks) and create a symlink on Scratch (at 0.14.6.) Everything syncs fine (actual symlink isn't synced between the machines, but no errors or syncing issues are present.)

Images no 4) I create a symlink on Fractal (at 0.14.24) Everything appears fine on Scratch but Fractal is stuck at 99%

Images no 5) I upgrade Scratch to 0.14.24 now both machines are stuck at 99% syncing and show the TestSymlink folder as 'Out of Sync'. Images no 5-1 show the items that failed (they're both symlinks.)

On Scratch the symlink was created via command line

    mklink "C:\Users\xxx\TestSymlinks\subfolder-from-scratch\test-symlink2.plgx" "C:\Users\xxx\TestSymlinks\SourceForgeUpdateChecker.plgx"

On Fractal the symlink was created via a shell plugin that allows me to drag a file to another folder and drop either a Hardlink or a Symbolic Link - in this case I dropped a Symbolic Link.
Confirmed on my own Windows 10, v0.14.25-rc.2. It's ironic that we didn't even manage to *disable* symlink handling properly on Windows.

rename.from: Syncing fails with 'A required privilege is not held by the client'
rename.to: Syncing fails with 'A required privilege is not held by the client' on Windows with symlinks

body: Great - thanks for fixing it so quickly.

@calmh Just tested with the 0.14.26 build and this issue is fixed (i.e. no 'privilege not held' error) but now the folder remains out of sync with a new error ('symlinks not supported'.) Previously there was an advanced setting to 'ignore symlinks' that disappeared in 0.14.24 which I think is still necessary, otherwise you end up with this:

![combined out of sync image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1922249/24681920/36e5234a-1965-11e7-81cf-6d5bfd679462.png)

I think the thinking was that symlinks are not special enough, in general, to warrant a toggle. Windows is the special case here though, when it is syncing against something non-Windows and also there are symlinks in that folder. The correct solution there is to ignore them by name using the regular ignore process.
@calmh Thanks, I'll implement some naming scheme for symlinks so I can add a single ignore rule.

> The correct solution there is to ignore them by name using the regular ignore process.

Actually, arguably, the correct solution is to warn the user, give them the opportunity to ignore, and also instruct them that the special local security policy setting, "Security Settings / Local Policies / Security Options / Create symbolic links" is needed for non-Admins to manage symlinks.

@calmh I implemented an ignore pattern for symlinks and it worked, my remote machine is no longer 'Out of Sync'. But there is one odd thing. The local machine that contains all the symlinks states a value of 7732 files under the 'Local State' in the UI. If I ignore a regular file that number will adjust, but when I added the ignore pattern for the symlinks that number doesn't change (I thought it'd go down by 97.) So the 'Local State' on the machine isn't counting the symlinks (whether there's an ignore pattern for them or not) but it obviously is sending the names of the symlinks (when there isn't an ignore pattern) to the remote machine (as the remote machine was previously complaining about the symlinks.) So until I was able to access the remote machine I didn't know if the ignore pattern for the symlinks was working.
If it's already in the index, which it is, it' expected.
I wonder if it's not just that we don't count symlinks as files at all
